file_content.text: Declaration: I have completed a full analysis of my functions, master.
I am ready to liquidate high-threat undesirables with one-hundred percent efficiency, as the Maker intended.
We will destroy the Empire's threats without restraint or remorse.
I expect nothing less.
Praise: Hearing you speak is like reviewing my programming logs. We will function well together, master.
I enjoy disposing of low-threat undesirables, as well. I trust that won't be a problem?
I have many types of enemies.
Assurance: I have been inactive for many years, master. You will find I am not a picky liquidator.
Relax your trigger finger unless I say otherwise, droid. Some bounties are wanted alive.
I don't always kill targets.
Criticism: Capture and imprisonment are inefficient procedures, master. Consider adopting an "all disintegrations" policy.
My missions occasionally require assassination. You'll be a valuable asset.
I'll have use for you.
Acknowledgment: I did not assume you reactivated me for my extensive cooking protocols, master--though they are impeccable.
Who is this "Maker"? Your designer?
The "Maker"?
Correction: The Maker defies simple organic classifications, master. The Maker not only provides form and function, but also marks the undesirables who deserve liquidation.
In the end, I am merely a humble servant of the Maker's infallible purpose.
I don't answer to your Maker--and neither do you. You're mine.
Serve me--and only me.
Confirmation: Of course I am yours, master. The Maker would not have it any other way.
Your belief system is more complex than your simple functions would indicate.
Interesting philosophy.
Dismissal: Simplicity is for organics, master. Er... no offense intended.
You're spouting gibberish, droid. Your logic processors must be failing.
You're defective.
Argument: Perform whatever diagnostics you wish, master. All my systems are in prime condition.
Do you possess any capabilities besides killing people? Something more constructive, perhaps?
What about peaceful functions?
Recommendation: The HK-51 series was not designed for manual labor, master. If you need to build something, I suggest using a construction droid.
Oath: While aboard your starship, I will maintain constant vigilance. You may rest easy here. Your absolute security occupies my every calculation.
I'm rarely on this ship. We'll spend most of our time planetside.
We won't be here often.
Encouragement: I can provide security anywhere. A simple nod is all I require to activate my combat protocols.
Not everyone on this ship can be trusted. I'm counting on you to watch my back.
Keep an eye on my crew.
Compliance: No organic on this vessel poses even the slightest threat while I remain functional.
I'd better not wake up to find you watching me sleep.
Just stay out of my quarters.
Agreement: Proper vigilance requires constant patrol. I will never linger in your presence for long.
I anticipate liquidating a great many undesirables in your service, master.
Report: After a thorough analysis, I have determined you are the most efficient master I could possibly serve.
Your position with the Emperor will permit us to hunt high-ranking undesirables indefinitely.
While the logic of your unorthodox methods remains impenetrable, you are nonetheless a rising power in the Empire.
You display an extraordinary talent for finding the galaxy's most elusive undesirables. And when you fail, they find you instead.
Your ability to infiltrate the undesirables' ranks permits me a level of access to them I would never otherwise possess.
Clearly, the Maker desires us to gloriously liquidate the Empire's enemies together. I find this prospect highly agreeable.
You are an obedient, efficient executioner.
You will serve me well.
Flattery: You set a fine example for me.
Another enthusiastic slave for my collection. How delightful.
Yes, I'm a wonderful master.
Persuasion: I prefer to think of you as a hand, with me as your fingers. Deadly, deadly fingers....
I can always use an extra blaster--especially one that keeps his cool in a fight.
Me, too.
Testimonial: I maintain a constant operating temperature of twenty degrees, even while in combat.
My work requires precise attention to detail. You leave nothing to chance.
As do I.
Humility: Randomness only exists for those unable to pay attention. Extraordinary focus is one of my finest qualities.
You may be the only member of my crew I can truly rely on.
I appreciate your loyalty.
Sentiment: That goes without saying, master. There is, however, a way to ensure your statement always remains true.
Your "Maker" was no divine entity. It was an organic being, just like me.
There is no "Maker"!
Appeasement: Your capacity for humor never ceases to impress. However, we must set aside levity for the moment.
Dilemma: The possibility exists I could be reprogrammed into serving a different and far less efficient master. This is unacceptable.
Solution: I have obtained a behavioral modification code that will permanently assign my functions to you. Once activated, it cannot be reversed.
You will serve no one else--not even your "Maker."
Activate it immediately.
Reassurance: There is no need to feel threatened by the Maker, master. This was always part of my final programming.
What if your Maker decides you should no longer serve me?
Not even by the Maker?
Didacticism: Oh, master, do not be silly. The Maker would not provide this opportunity if I was not meant to use it.
You might outlive me. Then what?
What happens when I die?
Explanation: You may assign me to the heir of your choice at any time. Consider me part of your family line, master.
Declaration: Activating loyalty permanence protocols now. Stand by for confirmation. If I attack you, it means something has gone wrong....
Confirmation: I will liquidate undesirables in your service to the limit of my function. This is a great gift to us both. Congratulations, master!
Announcement: I have unexpected good news, master. In the process of purging my efficiency-reducing subroutine, I discovered a series of combat protocol improvements.
My liquidation procedures are greatly enhanced. The Republic undesirables will tremble before my efficiency.
Fear is a powerful weapon. Use it wisely, and we will crush our enemies.
Show them true terror.
Compliment: You have a gift for poetry, master.
There's nothing wrong with most undesirables that a little trembling and liquidation can't fix.
I like it when foes tremble.
Agreement: You translated the words straight from my vocabulator, master.
There's bound to be somebody out there who needs your special attention.
Let's go make trouble.
Calculation: Current estimates place the number of undesirables at well over sixteen trillion, master. I look forward to meeting all of them.
Upgrades are always useful. Give me a full briefing on these enhancements.
Good. List your new functions.
Compliance: Targeting systems and reaction time have increased fifteen point eight one percent. My database of organic weak points has more than tripled, master.
Leave the intimidation to me. Focus on destroying my enemies.
Causing panic is my job.
Request: Give me the opportunity to display my full range of talents. You will not be disappointed, master.
You aren't as frightening as you like to think. I've seen more intimidating astromechs.
You don't scare anyone.
Question: Can an astromech disassemble every one of an undesirable's vital organs at the same time? I think not, master.
Assessment: I am finally the engine of liquidation the Maker always intended. We should celebrate my ascension with some especially memorable carnage!
I see you're still functional. Your "liquidation" must have been a success.
Revelation: The sabotage protocols have ceased operations, master. I fulfilled my programming.
Analysis: My systems are operating at ninety-three point six two percent efficiency and rising. I predict restoration to full functionality within two days.
Hint: My central learning chip always benefits from liquidating new and exciting undesirables, master. A happy coincidence, agreed?
Statement: The sabotage protocols in my system matrix continue operating, master. Premature deactivation appears inevitable unless I terminate this subroutine.
However, virtually all undesirables I was programmed to liquidate are invalid. They have succumbed to natural causes, various misadventures and random homicides.
Only three survivors remain on my target list. They have eluded the Empire for years, but I have learned their present locations.
And you're sure eliminating even one of these targets will save you?
Liquidating them helps you?
Why were you able to find these people when the whole Empire failed to?
An impressive feat.
Explanation: My target acquisition algorithms are unimpeachable, master. If it makes you feel better, the process took nearly ten times what it should have.
My target list is far more important. Continue serving me until I say otherwise.
We don't have time for this.
Hint: My sonoreceptors will be non-functioning if I do not take action soon, master. Besides, I am confident you will appreciate my targets.
First briefing: Jedi Master Valara has operated on Imperial planets for years, helping cowardly Sith acolytes escape their training and join the Jedi Order.
He is currently smuggling traitorous Sith organics off Taris. I have obtained the coded signal runaway acolytes use to summon his aid.
You'll send a fake signal and lure him into a trap. Perfect.
You can ambush him.
Anyone who can survive Taris's dangers is a challenging foe.
This Jedi must be tough.
Agreement: Master Valara possesses a talent for survival well beyond most organics. Unfortunately for him, he has never met me.
I'd rather see that Jedi take all our weakest recruits than spend the resources to feed, clothe and train them.
He's welcome to the fools.
Counterpoint: Weak Sith make useful target practice for the strong. Better that than bolstering your enemy's ranks, agreed?
Second briefing: Doctor Hu Marell is the enemy's top battlefield surgeon. His cybernetic enhancements keep wounded soldiers alive and fighting.
Doctor Marell currently saves injured Republic troops at a secret hospital on the planet Quesh. I have his coordinates and an ideal attack vector.
Eliminating this doctor not only stops the Republic from keeping soldiers in the war, it destroys their morale.
He's a worthy target.
Agreement: I could not have stated it better myself, master.
How many wounded Republic troops will perish in your assault?
Will soldiers die, too?
Description: My approach pattern will lead directly through the hospital's burn unit. Collateral damage will be appropriately impressive.
He's only a doctor. Surely there are better uses of your time?
Liquidating him is pointless.
Truism: How many Republic troops healed by Doctor Marell will go on to kill our brave Imperial soldiers? Think of them, master.
Third briefing: One of the Empire's most notorious traitors is hiding in plain sight, posing as an information broker on Nar Shaddaa.
During the last war, he betrayed the Third Imperial Assault Fleet and escaped with a sizeable Republic bribe--which he used for facial reconfiguration.
How many warships were destroyed by this betrayal?
What happened to the fleet?
Summation: The fleet was ambushed by a sizable Republic force. Our losses exceeded eighty percent of the vessels, and over twenty thousand Imperial organics.
The traitor's new face can't be very convincing if you tracked him down that easily.
I can't believe you found him.
Objection: This is the result of over three-hundred million speech pattern surveys. No other droid model--or organic--is equipped to perform that.
You don't have to sell me, droid. If shooting this man will fix you, I'm all for it.
Anything to repair you.
Praise: Truly, your lethality is matched only by your generosity. That is a rare combination, master.
List: Braga, Tol... Jedi Knight. Status unknown. Tavus, Harron... Lieutenant, Special Forces. Status unknown. Pollaran, Darmas. Information broker. Status unknown.
Confession: I have detected an anomaly in my subroutines. The target list I was programmed with years ago remains active in my memory core.
The only targets you need to worry about are the ones I assign you. Remove that list from your memory.
Delete that old data.
Alert: I am unable to comply, master. I have made multiple attempts to purge the data without success.
Is that old data causing you to malfunction?
Is that a problem for you?
Confirmation: My operating efficiency has dropped by twenty-one point four nine percent, master.
More enemies for us to liquidate? We'll take them in alphabetical order.
Let's find these targets.
Complication: The list is highly outdated, master. All profiles are currently registering as "status unknown." It will take some time to revise this information.
Conclusion: My failure to liquidate the programmed undesirables is causing a cascade failure of vital systems.
This sabotage protocol is a fail-safe to deactivate me in the event of enemy capture. It will eventually result in permanent shutdown.
You're a droid. If your systems fail, I'll replace them.
I'll rebuild you.
Objection: My personality matrix will be destroyed by that procedure, master. I would rather be atomized than reconstituted in a lesser form.
You served me well, but nothing lasts forever.
It was nice knowing you.
Retort: Master, I was constructed to provide service well beyond your average lifespan. Deactivation at my current service level is simply unwarranted.
Leave it to the Empire to booby-trap its assassins.
Stupid Imperials.
Disclaimer: While I admire the intent behind this sabotage, it does create an awkward situation.
Droids like you shouldn't serve our enemy. This precaution makes perfect sense.
A standard Imperial procedure.
Qualification: I will not argue with your analysis, master. I will simply observe its extreme inconvenience.
There must be some way to end this subroutine and restore your full functionality.
How do we prevent that?
Perplexity: I have conducted an extensive search for the protocols to end this annoyance. They do not exist within my memory core.
After everything I went through to reactivate you, you're falling apart on me. I should scrap you right now and be done.
You defective pile of junk.
Sentiment: Your concern for my well-being is most appreciated.
Investigation: My original programmer is deceased. Manually deleting the subroutine is impossible, but perhaps it can be terminated another way.
Request: While I search for a solution, please do not mention my predicament to your crew. It is important they continue to fear me.
This gives my processors pause. Was it always the Maker's will that I alone would complete our programmed function to liquidate undesirables?
Never second-guess your fate. Embrace it. Hesitation is weakness.
Don't question--act.
Compliment: Sometimes I envy your simplistic outlook, master. It must be liberating to discard all reasoning.
Quite the deep thinker, aren't we? You're a master of idle speculation.
What an odd droid you are.
Stipulation: If by "idle" you mean "not liquidating undesirables," and by "speculation" you mean "conducting proactive analysis," then I agree.
Quit complaining. You get to shoot people. What more do you need?
You think too much.
Flattery: You always know just how to inspire my behavior protocols, master.
A good assassin works alone--and adapts to changing circumstances.
Just do your duty.
Resignation: I suppose you have a point, master. The Maker's process will be revealed in time.
If I could reactivate you, there's hope for the rest of your production line.
Other HK units may be freed.
Admission: That is a pleasing theory, master. Becoming the vanguard of my production line's return would be flattering.
Droids don't have a destiny. I'm the only one commanding your functions.
There is no "Maker."
Appeasement: It is charming you believe that, master. I forget how much organics crave a sense of control.
By my calculations, HK-51 units would have ended the war five point three-two years ago with the Republic's complete collapse into anarchy.
Our time will come. Better late than never.
We'll get there eventually.
Lament: I abhor lateness, master. The inefficiency irritates my circuits.
That's a bold claim. Is there evidence to support it?
How did you determine this?
Revelation: The HK-51 series was provided a detailed list of critical undesirables. To liquidate even half would have thrown the enemy into chaos.
It will take more than a few assassin droids to crush the Republic.
You overstate your importance.
Justification: You have seen the efficiency with which I liquidate undesirables, master. Imagine if my entire production line remained active.
Manifesto: It is my highest function to see the Republic fall. Its destruction will be a lesson to all who oppose the Sith Empire.
Observation: This has been a highly productive interaction. I have a renewed sense of purpose. Thank you, master.
Commentary: My updated galactic history data indicates I missed depressingly little during my unscheduled shutdown. I am disappointed to note the Republic still stands.
The sacking of Coruscant was impressive, but the Empire failed to finish liquidating the enemy. That peace treaty was highly inefficient, master.
This time, there will be no mercy. We will conquer the Republic.
The war has begun again.
Contemplation: Perhaps I should be grateful the war waited for my reactivation.
You never play with your victims before finishing them off?
Inefficient, but fun.
Advice: Self-amusement at the expense of immediate liquidation invites failure. Never give the undesirables an even break.
There's a lot more bounties in peacetime. Why hire someone like me when you can send an army to do the job?
But good for my business.
Suggestion: Regardless of politics, assassins never run out of assignments.
We needed time to consolidate our position and gather strength. The Empire is more powerful, now.
It was a strategic withdrawal.
Counterpoint: The Republic undesirables are also more powerful--and motivated to resist. It is better to exterminate hope than let it breed.
Inefficient? What makes you say that?
How so?
Instruction: Pausing in the middle of liquidating undesirables allows them to gather strength and potentially regroup. This creates extra work for you.
The treaty wasn't my idea. The Emperor made that call.
Don't blame me for that.
Decision: I will compose a memo to the Emperor detailing his failure of leadership. He should learn from his mistakes.
Fact: The Empire needs a dedicated efficiency expert like myself. There is substantial room for improvement of its annihilation procedures.
The Sith spend as much time fighting each other as they do the Jedi. This is simply wasteful.
Sith are strong because we eliminate the weak among us.
Sith thrive through conflict.
Observation: While I fully support liquidation as a problem-solving strategy, it seems wise to pause inter-Sith hostilities until the Jedi are eradicated.
The Jedi talk about their problems. We prefer a more direct approach.
Revenge is the Sith way.
A united Sith Order would destroy everything in its path.
I agree with you.
Offer: I can activate my manifesto protocols at any time, master. I will happily compose a convincing argument you can share with other Sith.
Imperial Intelligence expends far too much effort on information-gathering. The entire organization should be converted to full-time liquidators.
Without proper intelligence, how would we know whom to assassinate?
Your logic is flawed.
Dismissal: There is no need for complex filtering, master. If someone serves the Republic, schedule them for liquidation.
With our talent for infiltration, we wouldn't have much difficulty getting close to targets.
An interesting concept.
Truism: Getting close is never the issue, master. The challenge is getting away. Enemy law enforcement has little appreciation for our work.
Bounty hunters should be drafted into the military and organized as the First Imperial Assassination Corps. Liquidations would be swift and glorious.
Bounty hunters work best alone--and we don't take orders from anybody.
That would never work.
Hypothetical: Even if those orders were simply "liquidate all Republic targets with extreme prejudice"?
I'll work for anyone if they can meet my price. Just don't ask me to wear a uniform.
If the pay is good, I'm ready.
Concession: Uniforms are mostly for parades, master. It is difficult to imagine you marching in step with anyone.
Conclusion: I will dedicate a small portion of my processors to developing new efficiency-increasing methods. I will inform you when I have recommendations.
Until then, we should resume liquidating the undesirables. They have lived far too long.
Know what would increase your efficiency? Tearing out your vocabulator.
Shut up or shut down.
Acknowledgment: Message received and understood, master. Consider this discussion terminated.
Declaration: I have new information to share with you, master. When we come to a lull in our liquidations, we should converse.
Prompt: I have sensitive information to share with you, master. Only your starship provides the appropriate security level.
Statement: I have no information for you, master. Shall we continue liquidating the undesirables?
Assurance: My target knew great terror before his liquidation. My only regret is that the remaining two undesirables on my list have moved to unknown coordinates.
What matters is, an enemy of the Empire has been eliminated. No one escapes our justice.
You have done well.
Flattery: Your inspiring words caused a momentary flutter in my circuits, master.
It's always useful to leave a little fear in your wake. Gives people something to remember you by.
Terror is good.
Disclaimer: I neglected to leave survivors, master. Rest assured, I will follow your advice next time.
One out of three is better than none.
Win some, lose some.
Philosophy: When you put things that way, it is difficult to argue.
I don't need to be seen with the galaxy's most hunted droid. I trust you eliminated all witnesses?
I hope you were discreet.
Query: Really, master... can you honestly imagine me leaving survivors?
I want the other two dead before the year is out, understood?
Start hunting them now.
Praise: Your commitment to the Maker's work never ceases to impress, master.
We have more important concerns. Your obligation to the Empire is fulfilled. Now you serve me.
Let them go.
Confirmation: Understood, master. I will trust in the Maker to place these targets in my path at a future date.
The Emperor will be pleased when these targets are eliminated.
Time to end this.
Addendum: More importantly, I will continue offering you flawless service. And that is invaluable.
How fortunate you should locate these people--just when your existence depends on it.
That's too lucky.
Confession: I used your vessel's computer in my search, master. If you notice certain operational inefficiencies, I am certain they are not my fault.
Any bounty still alive after this long must be worth a lot.
Sounds profitable.
Lament: Just the opposite, master. The targets' bounties have not been updated in years. Taking inflation into account, the profit is low.
Affirmation: The destructive subroutine will end immediately when I fulfill my programming. The only question now is, who to liquidate?
Admission: I am rather fond of this liquidation plan, myself.
Conundrum: It is impossible to liquidate all three undesirables, master. Their present coordinates have a limited duration. I must strike at one of them immediately.
As my master, you should direct my efforts. Who would you prefer I focus on: the Jedi Master, the Republic surgeon or the traitor?
Always aim for the most powerful enemy. Hunt down the Jedi. We'll deal with the other two later.
Eliminate the Jedi.
Acknowledgment: Your logic is most persuasive, master. I depart for Taris immediately.
Let's hit the Republic where it will hurt the most. Eliminate the surgeon on Quesh.
Stop the Republic surgeon.
Acknowledgment: I promise to inflict maximum pain, master. I will return shortly.
No one betrays the Empire and gets away with it. Bring that information broker to justice.
Hunt down that traitor.
Acknowledgment: Consider his justice served, master. I depart for Nar Shaddaa immediately.
Rumination: It appears many of my fellow HK-51 units will remain frozen indefinitely. What an inefficient fate.
Conjecture: The galaxy would be a different place if my transport had not crashed. Many Republic undesirables would be long since liquidated.
Query: Would it not be wiser to eradicate the Jedi before "directly approaching" each other?
Announcement: I look forward to my next liquidation.
Observation: Your gear suits you well, master. It veritably screams "fear me."
Assurance: My combat protocols and sociopathic personality matrix remain at your command.
Request: Please provide me with a new undesirable to liquidate.
Confession: Serving such a highly-trained killer is a great honor, master.
Alert: My combat processors are entering a boredom loop, master.
Rumination: Do you suppose our targets appreciate that they are liquidated by the best in the galaxy?
Inspiration: The Empire will never fall while we serve it, master. Onward to victory!
Contemplation: The Maker placed us together to enable maximum carnage.
Flattery: Your liquidation procedures are impressive, master--almost as much as my own.
